title: Proofing on Film
content:
Having the advantage of being employed in the composition department of a small newspaper, I used the RIP at our disposal to produce some broadsheet-sized proofs of my font. By setting up my PDF to be reverse, I got my letter-forms in black on transparent. The resolution is insane! It's also very handy for comparing shapes non-digitally, because I can lay multiple transparent sheets over each other.

Anyone tried this or have any other ways to proof that others might want to know about?
author: soidjte

comments.content:
It sounds pretty good. Although you probably have to lay the film over a white background, to be able to judge any shapes. But the resolution is insane, so I guess it's a very good proof indeed. :)

Though, film material is quite expensive as far as I know. ;)

Yeah I'm laying them on a lightboard and using a loupe if I'm checking small text. The film is kind of expensive, but since we do it by the roll we always end up with less than a full broadsheet of film left, which I've started using for my proofs rather than throwing it out. Our laser printers at work suck, and so does the one I have at home, so this is really my only high quality hardproof option.
